From this point of view it is a fine custom that we have inherited from our forefathers (if we were only true to it now) to appeal to the juror with this formula—“to do what he can consistently with his sacred honour.'' This form of appeal is in keeping with what I said a moment ago would be morally right for 3 judge to concede to a friend. For supposing that we were bound to do everything that our friends desired, ‚such relations would have to be aecounted not friendships but 45 conspiracies. But 1 am speaking here of ordinary friendships; for among men who are ideally wise and perfect such situations cannot arise.
